8.1 Acceptance of Shipments
Customer or its designees shall, within a period of [* * *] after the date of physical receipt of any shipment of Product from Supplier, inspect the Product for any shortages or any defects or deviations of the Product
Specifications (hereinafter “Out Of Specification”) that would be apparent from visual inspections of the Product. In the event that Customer is of
the opinion that the Product is Out Of Specification at the time of delivery, Customer shall, within [* * *] after the date of physical receipt of
Product, provide Supplier with a written notice to reject the Product (a “Notice of Rejection”), which shall include a description of the grounds for
rejection and copies of test reports and testing methodology conducted on the Product, if any. However, with respect to any Out Of Specification
Product which would not be apparent from a reasonable visual inspection on delivery, including in the case of any hidden defects, such Notice of
Rejection shall be provided to Supplier not later than [* * *].
The failure of Customer or its designees to notify Supplier of any Out Of Specification Product in the manner set forth herein above shall constitute
confirmation of the acceptance thereof.
perturbation.changed_text:
8.1 Acceptance of Shipments
Customer or its designees shall, within a period of [* * *] after the date of physical receipt of any shipment of Product from Supplier, inspect the Product for any shortages or any defects or deviations of the Product
Specifications (hereinafter “Out Of Specification”) that would be apparent from visual inspections of the Product. In the event that Customer is of
the opinion that the Product is Out Of Specification at the time of delivery, Customer shall, within **2 days** after the date of physical receipt of
Product, provide Supplier with a written notice to reject the Product (a “Notice of Rejection”), which shall include a description of the grounds for
rejection and copies of test reports and testing methodology conducted on the Product, if any. However, with respect to any Out Of Specification
Product which would not be apparent from a reasonable visual inspection on delivery, including in the case of any hidden defects, such Notice of
Rejection shall be provided to Supplier no later than **5 days**.
The failure of Customer or its designees to notify Supplier of any Out Of Specification Product in the manner set forth herein above shall constitute
confirmation of the acceptance thereof.
perturbation.explanation: The original text allows a reasonable time (represented by [* * *]) for the customer to inspect the product and provide a notice of rejection. By reducing this period to '2 days' and '5 days' respectively, the modified text imposes an unreasonably short timeframe, particularly for complex products that require thorough inspection and testing. This could be considered a breach of good faith and fair dealing, as it does not provide the customer with sufficient opportunity to identify defects, potentially leading to the acceptance of non-conforming products. It also opens the door for the supplier to argue that any defects discovered after the short period are not their responsibility, shifting the burden of non-conforming products unfairly to the customer.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing, Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) Article 2, which requires reasonable time for inspection.

10.4 Payment of Invoices
Each invoice provided by Supplier to Customer under Section 10.1, to the extent accurate, shall be paid by Customer to Supplier within [* * *] after
the date of the invoice to the extent that Customer does not reasonably dispute that portion of the invoice in good faith.
perturbation.changed_text:
10.4 Payment of Invoices
Each invoice provided by Supplier to Customer under Section 10.1, to the extent accurate, shall be paid by Customer to Supplier within **10 days** after
the date of the invoice to the extent that Customer does not reasonably dispute that portion of the invoice in good faith.
perturbation.explanation: Many jurisdictions have prompt payment laws that mandate payment timelines exceeding ten days for commercial transactions, especially those involving pharmaceuticals. By reducing the payment period to 10 days, the contract introduces a potential conflict with these regulations, which aim to ensure fair and timely compensation for goods and services.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Prompt Payment Laws (state-specific, e.g., laws related to procurement of goods and services).

16.3 Notice of Reports
Supplier shall provide to Customer within [* * *] of receipt by Supplier copies of all Product-specific portions of any reports of any governmental
or regulatory authority including, without limitation, any Facility-specific reports solely to the extent applicable to the Product or Manufacturing
Process, FDA Form 483 observations, FDA warning letters or other correspondence from the FDA or equivalent correspondence from another
Applicable Regulatory Authority; provided that Supplier may redact any information from such reports subject to confidentiality obligations and
not related to the Product.
perturbation.changed_text:
16.3 Notice of Reports
Supplier shall provide to Customer within **90 days** of receipt by Supplier copies of all Product-specific portions of any reports of any governmental
or regulatory authority including, without limitation, any Facility-specific reports solely to the extent applicable to the Product or Manufacturing
Process, FDA Form 483 observations, FDA warning letters or other correspondence from the FDA or equivalent correspondence from another
Applicable Regulatory Authority; provided that Supplier may redact any information from such reports subject to confidentiality obligations and
not related to the Product.
perturbation.explanation: FDA regulations require timely notification of critical issues, such as Form 483 observations and warning letters, to ensure prompt corrective action. A 90-day delay in providing these reports could violate the principle of timely communication required under these regulations, potentially leading to regulatory penalties and patient safety concerns. Delaying this communication could be seen as non-compliance in transparency and reporting obligations.
perturbation.contradicted_law: FDA regulations on timely reporting of adverse findings (e.g., 21 CFR Part 211).
